data.title: Dear Duolingo: Do other languages have diminutives?
data.meta_description: Languages have different ways of making tiny or cute versions of words, like "doggie" or "mommy." Here's how languages around the world make words cute!
data.text:
Welcome to another week of Dear Duolingo, an advice column just for learners. Catch up on past installments here.

Hallo zusammen! Iâ€™m Stefanie Schantl, and I'm a linguist working on Duolingo's German courseâ€”but you may also know me from posts about unique German words, colorful German idioms, and language predictions. This is my first Dear Duolingo column, and I'm excited to pull from another area of expertise: the internal structure of words. It's surprisingly complex when we compare languages from around the world!

Our question this week:

There's a lot to say about words for little things! The short answer is yes, languages all have ways to form diminutivesâ€”words that show something is small or sweet, or to show affection towards the wordâ€”but what words are eligible to be diminutives and how diminutives work can look really different.

Here are the languages we'll cover!

Examples of languages that use endings to form diminutives:

English

Spanish

German

Examples of language with other strategies for diminutives:

Chinese

Arabic

Norwegian

What are diminutives?

There are two main reasons for adjusting a word in a way that makes it sound more cute or playful: to show smallness or to express endearment. In English, we might call a tiny fish fishie, while someone calling their mom Mommy is showing their affection towards herâ€”instead of telling us anything about her size.

In many languages, diminutives are formed by adding a little something called a suffix to the end of a word. In English, the suffix is the sound "ee" (or /i/ in the International Phonetic Alphabet), which is typically written as "ie" or "y." (Because of English spelling rules, sometimes extra letters are written as well, so dog becomes doggie.) Spanish, on the other hand, clips the o from perro (dog) and adds -ito to give us perrito. German takes Hund, changes the u (IPA: ÊŠ) into umlaut Ã¼ (IPA: /Ê/) and adds -chen, turning it into HÃ¼ndchen.

While English adds -ie or -y to some nouns, there are many nouns we wouldnâ€™t turn into a diminutive at all. We donâ€™t usually call a small house a housie or a year a yeary if we want them to sound cutesy and small. But some languages do! Italian casa (house) becomes casetta and Spanish aÃ±o (year) becomes aÃ±ito. Famously, Spanish can even make a diminutive out of ahora (now), leading to many possible interpretations!

Let's take an even closer look at the complexities of diminutives in Spanish and German. ğŸ‘€

The diminutive in Spanish

The most common diminutive ending in Spanish is -ito for masculine nouns and -ita for feminine nouns.

Spanish can also add -ito/-ita to words other than nouns. In this way, pequeÃ±o and pequeÃ±a (small) become pequeÃ±ito and pequeÃ±ita (tiny). Sometimes, the diminutive suffix can even be doubledâ€”so the longer the word, the smaller the thing it refers to.

By now, you have probably noticed that Spanish diminutives always show the grammatical gender of the word. This is true even when the non-diminutive word doesnâ€™t show it with an -o or -a ending:

There's variation across speakers and Spanish dialects when it comes to complicated cases like la mano: Some people use la manita, and others say la manito. (And there are some other complexities I have to skip for nowâ€”let us know if you're interested in learning more!)

The diminutive in German

German nouns most commonly add -chen or -lein to form diminutives, and both endings turn the grammatical gender of any noun into neuter! Additionally, the stem-vowels a, o, and u (IPA: /aË/, /oË/, and /uË/) often change to their umlaut counterparts Ã¤, Ã¶, and Ã¼ (IPA: /É›Ë/, /Ã¸Ë/, and /yË/).

So, der Bub (the boy, masculine) becomes das BÃ¼bchen (the small boy, now grammatically neuter) and die Zunge (the tongue, feminine) becomes das ZÃ¼nglein (the small tongue, neuter). For nouns that were already grammatically neuter to begin with, the article remains the same, as in the case of das Brot (the bread, neuter) â†’ das BrÃ¶tchen (the bread roll, neuter).

This diminutive ending, and the change to neuter, is the reason why the German word for "girl," MÃ¤dchen, is grammatically neuter. It originated as the diminutive for Magd, which meant "maid" or "young girl"... and that diminutive, now with neuter gender, became the standard word!

The diminutive in Chinese

Similar to Spanish and German, Chinese sometimes adds a li'l bit to turn words into diminutivesâ€“but Chinese uses a prefix rather than suffix.

The diminutive in Arabic

Instead of using suffixes or reduplication, Arabic modifies words in a multi-step process that takes the core root consonants of a word and adds sounds between them! This process happens in three steps:

Identify the number of root consonants in a word.

Choose the diminutive pattern. There's one pattern for words with three root consonants and another if there are four root consonants.

Apply the pattern to the original word.

The two different patterns can be written like a formula, with "C" standing for the root consonants and the new vowels for the diminutive written in between them. For example, for words with three root consonants, the diminutive pattern is C1uC2ayC3, which means: Make the first root consonant the first sound of the word, then add a "u," then add the second root consonant, then add "ay," and end the word with the third root consonant.

The diminutive in Norwegian

Norwegian is related to both English and German, but unlike these two languages, it doesn't add a suffix to create a diminutive. Instead, Norwegian adds an adjective like mini (mini) or lille (little) to create compound words. That way, we get lillegutt (little boy) and minihus (tiny house). Notice that English uses mini- the same way, for example in minibus or miniseries!

Just a li'l complicated

While languages do differ quite a bit in *how* they form diminutives, they all have the ability to express this specific quality.
